I had to write an essay about "living" (but also getting to) mars and most of my classmates chose to argue that the average person totally could. I was the only one in the class to take the negative side and at the end of the year we had to do a debate with the info in our papers and the judge was my teacher and basically I was the only one in my team against my whole class and I won. They all thought that it was an easy win but looking at the hard cold facts it is a lot harder to live in Mars than you think!

So many assumptions in this video... the atmosphere's not the only thing that can protect you from solar radiation. Spacecraft can block sufficient amounts for passengers to incur a tolerable, almost negligible dose over their journey. Which doesn't have to take over 150 days either, you can shorten it by expending more fuel. This in turn also reduces the effects of microgravity on your body. The low atmospheric pressure on Mars will necessitate wearing a possibly hefty suit outside, but Mars' gravity is only a third of Earth's, so you'll have no trouble lifting heavy objects. You may see no vegetation outside, but you will be among the first to see landscapes no human has seen before. All the problems can be solved and things you lack are made up for things you'll have nowhere else. Sure, it's risky to go, but let's not exaggerate this risk and downplay its rewards.
